qas.question: Prior to 2004, what were US cable companies required to provide customers who rent HD set-top boxes?

answers.text: a set-top box with "functional" FireWire (IEEE 1394) on request

qas.question: When were boxes with "functional" FireWire no longer included in the FCC mandate?
Content is now protected by what encryption?

answers.text: duplication of content or simply limit the number of copies permitted

plausible_answers.text: set-top boxes with a set-top box with "functional" FireWire

qas.question: Prior to 2006, what were US cable companies required to provide customers who rent HD set-top boxes?
When were boxes with "functional" FireWire included in the FCC mandate?
Content is not protected by what encryption?

context: In the United States, as part of the FCC's plug and play agreement, cable companies are required to provide customers who rent HD <b4_0>set-top boxes with <a0_0>a set-top box with "functional" FireWire<b4_0/> (IEEE 1394) on request<a0_0/>. None of the direct broadcast satellite providers have offered this feature on any of their supported boxes, but some cable TV companies have. As of <a1_0><b5_0>July 2004<b5_0/><a1_0/>[update], boxes are not included in the FCC mandate. This content is protected by encryption known as <a2_0><b6_0>5C<b6_0/><a2_0/>. This encryption can prevent <a3_0><b7_0>duplication of content<b7_0/> or simply limit the number of copies permitted<a3_0/>, thus effectively denying most if not all fair use of the content.
